11 f. aeternae Vestae: the ever· burning fire on the hearth of Vesta was symbolical of the permanency of the state. ——incolurni Iove: z'.e. ‘while Jove's temple stands.' With the three verses, cf. Florus 2, 21, 3 patriae, nominis, togae, fascium oblitus (Antonius).

13 ff. hoc: emphatic, it was tlzz's very thing—Reguli: M. Atilius Regulus, consul 256 B.c., was cap- tured by the Carthaginians in Africa in 255 B.C. According to the common tradition he was sent to Rome in 250 B.c. to treat for

peace or to obtain at least an ex- change of prisonerS, but persuaded the Senate to decline to consider either proposition. Polybius does not refer to this mission, so that the correctness of the tradition has been called into question, but in Cicero's time it had become a favorite commonplace. Cf.
